title: 109_hr2807
content: The Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 expands and improves telehealth services under the Medicare program. It includes provisions for increasing the types of originating sites, facilitating services across state lines, and defining the Medicare program. Additionally, there are grant programs for the development of telehealth networks and reauthorization of existing programs. The Medicare Telehealth Enhancement Act of 2005 expands telehealth services by allowing access to all areas without geographic restrictions. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on store and forward technologies for telehealth services in Alaska, Hawaii, and other states. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on store and forward technologies for telehealth services in Alaska, Hawaii, and other states, assessing feasibility, advisability, and costs. A report with recommendations for legislation or administration action will be submitted to Congress within 18 months. SEC. 102. INCREASE IN NUMBER OF ORIGINATING SITES; CLARIFICATION. Increase in number of originating sites under the Social Security Act to include skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, and mental health clinics. Clarification provided on the term 'originating site' for eligibility determination purposes. The term 'originating site' is clarified for eligibility determination purposes, specifically for receiving a facility fee for telehealth services provided. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will work with stakeholders to promote multistate practitioner licensure for telehealth services under the Medicare program. Definitions for telehealth services, physicians, and practitioners are provided. The term "medicare program" refers to the health insurance program administered by the Secretary of Health and Human Services under title XVIII of the Social Security Act. Additionally, there is a grant program for the development of telehealth networks under HRSA. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make grants to eligible entities to expand access to healthcare services in rural, frontier, and urban medically underserved areas through telehealth. Eligible entities must submit an application containing required information. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will make grants to eligible entities to expand healthcare services in underserved areas through telehealth. The application must include details on grant need, planned activities, project sustainability, meeting healthcare needs of rural populations, and community involvement in network development. The application for grants to expand healthcare services through telehealth must demonstrate project viability, provider commitment, and integration of telehealth in the community to avoid redundancy and achieve economies of scale. Eligible entities include hospitals or health care providers in a network of community-based providers meeting specific criteria. Entities eligible for grants to expand healthcare services through telehealth must demonstrate use of the network for education or economic development as required by the Secretary. The organizations eligible for these grants include community or migrant health centers, local health departments, nonprofit hospitals, private practice health professionals, skilled nursing facilities, and publicly funded mental health facilities. Entities eligible for grants to expand healthcare services through telehealth include public schools, libraries, universities, colleges, local government entities, local health entities, health-related nonprofit foundations, and academic health centers. For-profit entities may be included as long as the grant recipient is a not-for-profit entity. The Secretary will prioritize financial assistance based on established procedures. The Secretary will prioritize financial assistance for healthcare providers in underserved areas who propose to form networks, demonstrate broad geographic coverage, develop telehealth systems, and use funds for rural hospitals and providers. The applicant will use the provided amounts for health care applications and to promote efficiency in resource use. They must demonstrate project viability through cost participation and show support from financial, institutional, and community sources. A detailed plan for coordinating system use by eligible entities is required to prioritize health care services over non-clinical uses. The Secretary will establish the maximum amount of grant awards for individual recipients. The Secretary will establish the maximum amount of grant awards for individual recipients under this section, which can be used for acquiring telehealth equipment and improving telecommunications facilities. This includes purchasing computer hardware, software, audio and video equipment, and providing technical assistance and instruction. The provision of technical assistance, instructional programming, demonstration projects for medical training, telenursing services for care coordination, promoting patient adherence to national guidelines for chronic diseases, and covering transmission costs and equipment maintenance. The curr_chunk discusses the permissible uses of funds for telehealth projects, including compensation for specialists, collaboration between healthcare providers, electronic archival of patient records, and data analysis for cost-effectiveness. Prohibited uses include acquiring real property and excessive equipment expenditures. The grant funds can be used for purchasing transmission equipment off-site, construction with minor renovations, and indirect costs not exceeding 15% of the total grant. The Secretary ensures no duplication of telehealth networks and coordinates with other agencies. State agencies and not-for-profit organizations collaborate to fund meritorious proposals through grant programs. The Secretary will conduct outreach activities to inform potential end users in rural and medically underserved areas about the program. Prompt implementation of the grant program is required, with an authorization of $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2006 and additional funding for subsequent years. SEC. 202. REAUTHORIZATION OF TELEHEALTH NETWORK AND TELEHEALTH RESOURCE CENTERS GRANT PROGRAMS. Subsection (s) of section 330I of the Public Health Service Act is amended to allocate $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2007 and necessary funds for fiscal years 2008 through 2012.
